How do you store your wine, though?
Even if you only store a few bottles for a short time, the fridge is not your best option.
With a dedicated wine cooler, also known as a wine fridge, you’ll be able to store your wines at a stable temperature. Wine is ruined by fluctuations in temperature so this is key. A broad range of 50 to 65 degrees Fahrenheit is the optimum storage temperature for reds while white is best kept between 45 and 55 degrees Fahrenheit. Champagne should be stored between 41 and 46 degrees Fahrenheit.
https://www.narrowsbar.com/best-wine-fridges/

It is a weird dream of mine to work in a winery, or a wine shop in Italy or France.

Champagne is not a very good wine, there are some exceptions, but with the same type of grapes, like Chardonnay, Burgundy wines are far better (Try a Chablis or a Mersault). And that's why we make sparkling wine, bubbles changes the almost ordinary wine in something very special.

There are a few imprecision in the video.

First there is "colored" champagne which is "Rosé". It's made with black grapes of course, but the grape's skin is not separated from the juice immediately.

And there are more than 3 type of champagne, depending on the sugar added to it :

Brut Nature = no added sugar and under 3 grams/litre of residual sugars
Extra-Brut = between 0 and 6 g/litre of residual sugars
Brut = less than 12 g/litre of residual sugars
Extra sec (or Extra Dry) = between 12 & 17 g/litre of residual sugars
Sec (or Dry) = between 17 & 32 g/litre of residual sugars
Demi-Sec = between 32 & 50 g/litre of residual sugars
Doux = more than 50 g/litre of residual sugars
(There is a tolerance of +/- 3g on the figures of residual sugars : i.e. a brut may have 15 g/litre)
